title: 108_hr2752
content:
The "Author, Consumer, and Computer Owner Protection and Security (ACCOPS) Act of 2003" authorizes appropriations for the Department of Justice to investigate and prosecute violations of title 17, United States Code. It also establishes the National Intellectual Property Law Enforcement Coordination Council to share law enforcement information related to copyright infringement and enhances criminal copyright reporting. SEC. 103 of the ACCOPS Act amends Section 2320(f) of title 28, US Code to require the Attorney General to submit biannual reports to the House and Senate Judiciary Committees. The Attorney General of the United States shall provide evidence to assist foreign authorities in determining copyright law violations or enforcing foreign copyright laws. This evidence includes details on the violation, technological means used, identity and location of the violator, and estimated financial loss. SEC. 202. LIMITATIONS.

The Attorney General shall not provide evidence under section 201 that is classified or should not be disclosed for national security reasons.

TITLE III--ANTI-PIRACY TOOLS

SEC. 301. CRIMINAL PENALTIES FOR PLACING WORKS ON COMPUTER NETWORKS. SEC. 301 amends Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, regarding criminal penalties for placing copyrighted works on computer networks accessible to the public. It defines unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works on a computer network as distributing at least 10 copies of the work with a retail value of over $2,500 within a 180-day period. The amendment to Chapter 89 of title 18, United States Code introduces a new section, Sec. 1822, which imposes fines or imprisonment for offering enabling software for download without clearly warning users of potential security and privacy risks and obtaining their consent. Enabling software is defined as software that allows third parties to store data on the user's computer or search other computers' contents over the Internet. Amendment to Table of Sections adds a new item. SEC. 303 imposes criminal penalties for false information in domain name registration. SEC. 303 imposes criminal penalties for providing fraudulent information when registering a domain name, with fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. The term 'domain name' refers to any alphanumeric designation registered with a domain name authority as part of an Internet address. Section 230(f)(1) of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 230(f)(1)) is amended by adding a new item to the table of sections for chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 304 amends Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code to prevent surreptitious recording in theaters. It includes unauthorized reproduction or recording of a motion picture in a theater. SEC. 305 establishes evidentiary standards for criminal willfulness. The amendment to Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code addresses the provision of false contact information to domain name authorities, considering it as evidence of willfulness in infringement cases. Additionally, the definition of a domain name is clarified as an alphanumeric designation registered with a domain name authority for an electronic address on the Internet. The term 'Internet' is defined in section 230(f)(1) of the Communications Act of 1934.
